items.title: App Aids Visually Impaired Fans to Navigate Lord's Cricket Ground
items.summary:
- *Waymap* has developed a GPS app offering precise indoor navigation at Lord’s stadium, enabling visually impaired fans to locate seats independently.
- The app uses a detailed digital scan of the stadium and requires personalized calibration for stride patterns.
- Initial trials reveal promise with some user-app adaptation needed; plans exist to expand to other sports venues.

items.title: Video Game Developers Face False Accusations of Using AI
items.summary: - Developers like Stamina Zero and Josh Caratelli are facing *false accusations* of using AI for art they commissioned or created by hand. - Critics highlight AI concerns such as *plagiarism, environmental impact, and quality*, but skepticism is now unfairly hurting genuine creators. - Proving non-AI origin is difficult, and the community must build *trust* amid rising fears and misinformation.

items.title: Meta wins AI copyright lawsuit as US judge rules against authors
items.summary: - A US judge ruled in favor of Meta in a lawsuit claiming copyright infringement for using authors' books to train AI. - The judge stated authors failed to prove their market was harmed, but noted that unauthorized AI training can be unlawful in other scenarios. - The ruling highlights the ongoing tension between *fair use* defense by AI firms and copyright protections for creators.

items.title: YouTube and Australia’s Under-16 Social Media Ban Debate
items.summary: - Australia’s online safety regulator recommends including **YouTube** in the under-16 social media ban due to exposure to harmful content and addictive features. - YouTube argues it should be exempt, highlighting its educational role and safety measures like YouTube Kids. - The ban restricts account creation, not logged-out viewing, aiming to protect children but retain educational access.

items.title: Meta CTO Joins New US Army Tech Corps as Lieutenant Colonel
items.summary:
- Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth calls joining the US Army's new tech corps 'the great honor of my life'.
- Detachment 201 enlists senior tech leaders from Meta, Palantir, OpenAI to integrate cutting-edge technology with military operations.
- The initiative reflects growing collaboration between the US military and tech giants to innovate warfare and logistics.

items.title: Dan Rath: the 10 funniest things I have ever seen (on the internet)
items.summary:
- Comedian Dan Rath shares his top 10 funniest internet clips, including legends like *Norm MacDonald*, *Rodney Dangerfield*, and *Joan Rivers*.
- He prefers classic humor and repeats favorites to boost his mood, avoiding social media but occasionally doomscrolling mundane info.
- Highlights include *pandemic-era comedy specials* by Eddie Pepitone and Robby Hoffman, plus unique performances by emerging comedians like Sam Campbell.

items.title: Young Iranians Struggle Amid Internet Blackout During Israeli Strikes
items.summary: - *Iran faced a near-total internet shutdown for 13 days* during Israeli strikes, severely limiting information access. - Young Iranians use *fragile proxy links and secret tunnels* to bypass government restrictions and communicate. - The blackout intensifies isolation amid war, leaving many relying on *foreign help and risking surveillance* on domestic apps.

items.title: How Hideo Kojima created yet another weird, wonderful world in Death Stranding 2
items.summary:
- *Death Stranding 2* reimagines a post-apocalyptic Australia with a dynamic, ever-changing landscape inspired by Australian New Wave cinema and directors like George Miller and Peter Weir.
- The game seduces players with its haunting, hallucinatory rhythms and interconnected player-built infrastructure, blending beauty and danger in an alien yet timeless world.
- Additional gaming content includes the uniquely thematic *Quantum Witch* and discussions on games' positive impacts on mental health, along with industry updates.

items.title: From Chimpanzini Bananini to Ballerina Cappuccina: how gen alpha went wild for Italian brain rot animals
items.summary:
- *Italian brain rot* is a viral meme trend among Gen Alpha and younger Gen Z, featuring absurd AI-generated animals with silly Italian-sounding names and nonsensical narration on TikTok.
- Characters like *Chimpanzini Bananini* and *Ballerina Cappuccina* have created a fandom with lore, wars, and songs, reflecting youth culture’s embrace of the surreal and silly.
- The trend illustrates how easy AI tools foster rapid meme creation, influencing young digital natives and shaping evolving online cultures.

items.title: Mirrors in space and underwater curtains: can technology buy us enough time to save the Arctic ice caps?
items.summary: - Arctic warming threatens research sites, prompting scientists to explore 61 innovative interventions to slow or reverse ice loss, including space mirrors and underwater curtains.  - Technologies like marine-cloud brightening and stratospheric aerosol injection are debated, with a focus on ethical, governance, and sustainability concerns. - While geoengineering faces criticism and legal challenges, researchers argue urgency in balancing risks, given climate change's rapid pace.

items.title: Second study finds Uber used opaque algorithm to dramatically boost profits
items.summary: - Two major academic studies from Columbia Business School and University of Oxford found Uber used *opaque algorithms* to raise *rider fares* and cut *driver pay* significantly since 2022-2023. - Uber’s *take rate* increased from about 32% to over 42% in the US, and from 25% to as high as 50% on some UK trips. - Uber denies unfair manipulation, claiming its pricing is *transparent*, fair, and guarantees drivers at least the national living wage.

items.title: The Outer Worlds 2, the most expensive Xbox game yet
items.summary: - *The Outer Worlds 2* is the first first-party Xbox game priced at $80, reflecting its larger, more in-depth content compared to the 2019 original. - Obsidian has significantly improved the *gunplay*, incorporating feedback from games like Destiny and Halo, delivering diverse combat and stealth options. - Powered by Unreal Engine 5, it offers seamless exploration without loading screens and deepens customization with more perks and flaws, justifying its premium cost.

items.title: US Investigates Tesla’s Robotaxi Following Reports of Erratic Driving
items.summary:
- The US safety regulator NHTSA is investigating Tesla’s recently launched Robotaxi service in Austin, Texas, after videos showed cars speeding and veering into wrong lanes.  
- Tesla’s CEO Elon Musk claimed the launch was successful, but some videos revealed safety glitches raising concerns.  
- Tesla’s Robotaxi program is critical amid falling sales, with NHTSA also examining Tesla’s Full-Self Driving mode due to prior fatal incidents.

items.title: The ‘fridge cigarette’: how gen Z reframed the smoking break
items.summary: - *‘Fridge cigarette’* is a new Gen Z term for a cold can of soda, popularized by a TikTok video with 3.8 million views. - It symbolizes the ritual and break-taking moment similar to smoking, but without health risks. - Reflects Gen Z’s focus on *health, wellbeing,* and *work-life balance* while embracing nostalgic social habits.

items.title: Tech in the Iran-Israel conflict: internet blackout, crypto burning and home camera spying
items.summary:
- The Iran-Israel conflict has escalated into **digital warfare** with Iran imposing a near-total **internet blackout** to prevent Israeli cyber incursions.
- Israeli-linked hackers claimed a **$90m cryptocurrency heist** from Iran’s Nobitex exchange and have reportedly hacked Iran’s state bank and hijacked home security cameras for intelligence gathering.
- Iran’s internet restrictions severely limit ordinary citizens’ access to information, and Israeli cyber attacks have been more successful in causing disruption.

items.title: ‘Trauma is messy, but music will come of it’: Jessica Curry on Shielding Songs
items.summary: - Jessica Curry, composer of acclaimed game soundtracks (e.g., *Everybody’s Gone to the Rapture*), endured severe personal trauma and isolation during Covid due to illness, losing family and facing serious health issues. - Her new album, *Shielding Songs*, reimagines her past work with ethereal choral arrangements, expressing themes of love, grief, isolation, and hope. - Despite ongoing health struggles, Curry has returned to composing, embracing change and transformation as she moves forward creatively.

items.title: Inside the No Space for Bezos movement in Venice
items.summary: - The *No Space for Bezos* movement opposes Jeff Bezos's lavish wedding in Venice, highlighting *disruption* from billionaire excess and the *impact on locals* and small businesses. - Activists emphasize the *obscenity* of one man renting a city and protest the city government's prioritization of billionaires over Venetians. - The protests connect broader critiques of *overconsumption, exploitation,* and the intertwining of *digital capitalism with authoritarian politics.*

items.title: YouTube Opposes eSafety Commissioner's Push to Include It in Under-16s Social Media Ban
items.summary:
- YouTube criticizes the eSafety commissioner’s call to include it in Australia’s under-16 social media ban, calling the advice *inconsistent* and ignoring parents and teachers.
- The eSafety commissioner advocates a “delay” with AI-based age verification to enforce the ban starting December 2025, though platforms face challenges meeting deadlines.
- YouTube argues its platform is for content viewing, not social interaction, has removed numerous harmful videos, and urges the government to maintain its exemption.

items.title: ‘It’s cheap but it’s not disposable’: why fast tech is a growing waste problem
UK Watchdog May Force Google to Offer Search Alternatives
items.summary: - The UK Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) plans to designate Google with "strategic market status," enabling tighter regulation. - Proposed rules include "choice screens" for users to select alternative search engines and fairer content ranking. - This marks a new regulatory milestone under the Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act, aiming to increase *user control* and foster *innovation* in UK tech.

items.title: WhatsApp banned on all US House of Representatives devices
items.summary: - The US House of Representatives has **banned WhatsApp** on all official devices citing **security risks** and lack of data encryption. - Other messaging apps like **Microsoft Teams, Wickr, Signal, iMessage, and FaceTime** are recommended alternatives. - The move follows concerns over **data transparency** and incidents involving encrypted apps like Signal in sensitive communications.

items.title: John Oliver on AI Slop: ‘Some of This Stuff Is Potentially Very Dangerous’
items.summary:
- John Oliver describes AI-generated content as '**AI slop**', a flood of cheap, professional-looking fake media that *floods social feeds* and often deceives users.
- He highlights the *dangers* including misinformation, environmental impact, and the erosion of belief in objective reality.
- Oliver warns AI slop is *hard to detect*, empowers bad actors, and is *likely to persist*, making it a *potentially very dangerous* societal issue.

items.title: YouTube Exemption Challenged in Australia's Under-16 Social Media Ban
items.summary:
- Australia's eSafety commissioner, Julie Inman Grant, urges including **YouTube** in the under-16s social media ban, countering the government's exemption for the platform.
- Research found nearly *40% of children* reported exposure to harmful content on YouTube, with issues like infinite scroll and AI chatbots cited as risks.
- The commissioner highlights that exempting YouTube contradicts the intent to reduce harm and calls for updated rules to cover specific risky features.

items.title: Death Stranding 2: On the Beach review – a hypnotising art-house game with an A-list cast
items.summary:
- *Death Stranding 2* is a *meditative*, art-house style game blending cargo delivery with deep narrative and poetic metaphors.
- Featuring an *A-list cast* including Norman Reedus and Elle Fanning, it explores themes of connection and loneliness in a post-apocalyptic world.
- Gameplay is rich and refined with meaningful combat and player interactions, highlighting that *"you are never truly alone"*.

items.title: OpenAI removes mentions of Jony Ive’s io after trademark dispute
items.summary: - OpenAI has removed online content about its $6.4bn deal with Jony Ive’s startup, io, following a trademark complaint from AI earbud maker iyO. - The dispute has led to a temporary takedown of promotional materials, but the acquisition deal remains unaffected. - The partnership aims to create a new AI-enabled device complementary to current Apple products, with launch expected next year.

items.title: Allison Williams on M3gan 2.0, AI, parenting & privilege
items.summary: - *Allison Williams* discusses her role in *M3gan 2.0* and her insights on AI’s ethical implications and dangers, especially concerning children’s exposure. - She critiques *toxic ‘momfluencer’ culture* for promoting unrealistic parenting standards and shares her podcast on motherhood and ageing. - Williams openly reflects on her *privilege* as a 'nepo baby' and the importance of gratitude in her career and life.

items.title: Is this the antidote to the housing crisis? The YouTube series showcasing chic – and tiny – abodes
items.summary: - The *YouTube series* Never Too Small showcases *innovative small homes* worldwide, emphasizing that comfort doesn’t require large spaces. - The *short episodes* feature stylish, functional micro-apartments and tiny houses with creative designs and smart living solutions. - The series challenges cultural norms around large homes, offering *inspiration during housing crises* and redefining what 'small' living means.

items.title: Marginalia mania: how ‘annotating’ books went from big no-no to Booktok’s next trend
items.summary: - The art of *marginalia*—annotating books with notes and tabs—is resurging among BookTok and Bookstagram communities, blending personal reflection with aesthetic appeal. - Annotating helps readers engage deeply with books, especially in popular genres like romance and 'romantasy', and creates a sense of personal and communal connection. - Beyond performance, marginalia records readers’ evolving thoughts and emotions, enriching the reading experience and preserving memories linked to books.

items.title: Impersonators Steal Elderly TikToks to Scam Viewers with Fake Stories
items.summary:
- Elderly TikTokers' videos are stolen and repurposed by impersonators to sell mass-produced goods under false charitable pretenses, such as fake cat shelters.
- Victims like George Tsaftarides and Charles Ray struggle to get platforms like TikTok to remove these scam accounts despite reporting identity theft.
- TikTok states policies prohibit impersonation, but enforcement is inconsistent, prompting some users to raise awareness rather than stop posting.

items.title: Recording Teens on Phones Reveals Dark Side of Social Media
items.summary: - Lauren Greenfield's Emmy-tipped documentary *Social Studies* captures the raw online and offline lives of teens, revealing issues like cyberbullying, addiction, and sexual exploitation. - The immersive series exposes how social media is engineered to be addictive, impacting youth well-being and parental relationships. - Greenfield’s work urges *collective action* to create safer environments, highlighting the absent adult role and the culture of constant comparison.

items.title: Do electric vehicles make people more carsick?
items.summary:
- Electric vehicles (EVs) are linked to increased motion sickness due to *lack of engine noise and vibrations*, which help the brain anticipate movement in traditional cars.  
- Features like *regenerative braking* cause gradual deceleration, a factor associated with heightened motion sickness.  
- Researchers suggest that *visual and vibrational cues* could help passengers adapt to EV motion, reducing nausea in the future.

items.title: 16 Billion Login Records Exposed; Users Urged to Change Passwords
items.summary: - Researchers uncovered **16 billion login records** in 30 datasets from malware called “infostealers” and prior breaches. - No new centralized breach at major companies, but exposure highlights risks from **poorly stored data**. - Experts urge users to adopt **multifactor authentication, password managers, and regular password updates** to mitigate risks.

items.title: Investing apps: which offer the most for beginners?
items.summary:
- Investing apps like Nutmeg, Moneybox, Dodl, Wealthify, and Moneyfarm offer *robo-adviser* services to simplify investing for beginners.
- These apps provide *ready-made portfolios* with varying risk levels, low minimum investments, and transparent fees ranging from approximately 0.15% to 0.98%.
- Features such as round-ups, thematic investing, and ESG options enhance ease of use and customize user portfolios while emphasizing the importance of FCA regulation and FSCS protection.

items.title: ‘It could get an orgasm out of a cabbage’: the best vibrators, tested
UK Investigates Amazon Over Delayed Payments to Grocery Suppliers
items.summary: The UK Groceries Code Adjudicator has launched an investigation into Amazon for allegedly failing to pay grocery suppliers on time, risking supplier stability and innovation. This probe highlights key compliance issues affecting the UK grocery sector, signaling significant regulatory scrutiny on major retailers. Suppliers are encouraged to submit evidence confidentially by August 8.

items.title: Chris Brown Pleads Not Guilty in Alleged London Nightclub Bottle Attack
items.summary: Chris Brown has pleaded not guilty to charges related to an alleged bottle attack at a London nightclub, facing a trial scheduled for October 2026. Despite the accusations, he continues his international tour, highlighting ongoing legal challenges amid his career. This case underscores the intersection of celebrity and criminal justice.

items.title: Immersive XR Experience Explores Psychosis in Abandoned Melbourne Mall
items.summary: The Door in Question is a deeply immersive XR production in a deserted Melbourne shopping center that simulates psychosis through VR and mixed reality, inspired by the creator’s personal experiences. It uniquely blends narrative and environment, offering a personal, sensory journey into altered mental states. This innovative approach highlights art’s power to transform abandoned spaces and mental health storytelling.

items.title: Uber's Algorithm Change Reduces Driver Earnings by Increasing Company Take
items.summary: A University of Oxford study reveals Uber's 2023 dynamic pricing algorithm has significantly increased the company's share of fares, reducing UK drivers' earnings and introducing unpredictability in pay. This insight underscores ongoing challenges for gig workers facing opaque wage structures in growing tech platforms.

items.title: 14 Expert Tips to Stay Cool During Heatwaves
items.summary: As global temperatures rise, heatwaves are becoming frequent and dangerous. Experts from worldwide hotspots share 14 practical tips to stay cool, from staying hydrated to choosing the right clothing and seeking shade. This guide is essential for anyone facing extreme heat, offering effective, expert-backed strategies to beat the heat safely.

items.title: Hideo Kojima Reflects on Connection and Challenges in Developing Death Stranding 2
items.author: Patricia Hernandez
items.summary: Hideo Kojima discusses the creative and logistical challenges behind Death Stranding 2, highlighting the impact of the pandemic on remote collaboration and his evolving vision of connection. Set largely in Australia, the sequel deepens the game's exploration of indirect human bonds, making it relevant for gamers intrigued by immersive, thoughtful storytelling.

items.title: UK Uber Drivers Earn Less per Hour Following Introduction of Dynamic Pricing
items.summary: A University of Oxford study reveals that UK Uber drivers earn substantially less hourly since the 2023 introduction of a dynamic pricing algorithm, despite passengers paying higher fares and Uber taking a larger cut. This highlights growing concerns over driver pay and fairness in gig economy work.

items.title: Garmin Forerunner 970 review: a premium upgrade for serious runners
items.author: Samuel Gibbs
items.summary: The Garmin Forerunner 970 sets a new standard for running watches with advanced metrics, brighter sapphire glass display, and a unique built-in torch. It enhances training with injury-prevention features and superior GPS accuracy, making it an essential tool for dedicated runners and triathletes seeking premium performance and smart features.

items.title: French App 'Poppins' Encourages Renting Underused Household Items to Promote Sharing Economy
items.author: Alexandra Topping
items.summary: The French app Poppins, co-founded by Lucie Basch, connects users to rent or borrow underused household items, promoting a sharing economy that reduces waste and consumption. With 40,000 users in weeks, it aims to foster ecological, economic, and social benefits by encouraging access over ownership. Its upcoming expansion highlights growing interest in sustainable consumption.

items.title: Marketing Missteps in Gaming: The MAGA Cap Controversy at Summer Games Fest
items.author: Keza MacDonald
items.summary: A smaller game studio's promotional stunt using a MAGA-themed cap at Summer Games Fest sparked criticism for insensitivity amid tense political contexts, highlighting the risks of using polarizing memes in marketing. The incident underscores the importance of cultural awareness and thoughtful community engagement in the gaming industry.

items.title: OpenAI CEO Accuses Meta of Poaching AI Talent with $100M Bonuses
items.summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman accused Meta of offering exorbitant $100 million signing bonuses to poach AI experts, highlighting intense competition for talent in AI development. Despite Meta's aggressive approach, Altman believes their focus on massive upfront pay overshadows mission-driven innovation, potentially hindering culture and progress.

items.title: WhatsApp AI Helper Accidentally Shares User's Private Number, Raising Privacy Concerns
items.summary: Meta's WhatsApp AI assistant mistakenly shared a private user's phone number instead of a customer service contact, exposing flaws in AI reliability and privacy safeguards. This incident highlights the risks of AI generating or accessing sensitive data inaccurately, emphasizing the need for transparency and improved safeguards in AI systems.

items.title: Amazon CEO Warns AI Will Reduce Corporate Workforce in Coming Years
items.summary: Amazon CEO Andrew Jassy warned that advances in AI, including generative AI and autonomous agents, will reduce the need for corporate employees within a few years. He urged staff to embrace AI skills to stay relevant as billions of AI agents transform workplaces globally. This highlights the urgent need for workforce adaptation amid AI-driven change.

items.title: Top Games to Play on Nintendo Switch 2 Beyond Mario Kart World
items.summary: Nintendo Switch 2 launches with Mario Kart World as a multiplayer hit, but its library lacks first-party titles. Several standout third-party games such as Hitman: World of Assassination, Cyberpunk 2077, and Yakuza 0 offer impressive ports and fresh experiences, making the new console compelling beyond Nintendo’s offerings.

items.title: What to do if your mobile phone account is hacked or number stolen
Maritime Cybersecurity and the Rising Threat of Shadow Fleets
items.summary: Maritime cyber experts at the Nordic Maritime Cyber Resilience Centre warn that cyber-attacks on ships are inevitable, with nation states exploiting digital vulnerabilities amid geopolitical tensions. Additionally, Russia's growing shadow fleet of unregulated tankers poses environmental and security risks, highlighting urgent challenges in maritime safety and sovereignty.
